item.title: Is the new Directive on discrimination against EU citizen workers just a futile effort?
item.description:
Despite public debate regarding EU citizens working in different Member States (“EU workers”), the Council and European Parliament have agreed on new legislation concerning this topic. Recently approved by the European Parliament, the new Directive focuses on enforcing existing rules against discrimination toward EU workers and will likely be adopted by the Council soon. Member States are given two years to implement this Directive. The Directive itself doesn’t modify existing rights related to EU worker free movement, but instead, clarifies the enforcement and application of rights granted by Article 45 TFEU and Regulation 492/2011...

item.title: Explaining the European Court of Justice's decisions on headscarf bans in the workplace
item.description:
Professor Steve Peers The European Court of Justice (ECJ) recently issued rulings on whether employers can prohibit employees from wearing headscarves at work. These rulings have garnered significant attention, although some of it stems from misunderstandings. This post aims to provide a clear explanation of the rulings. Background The EU has established laws against discrimination based on sex, nationality, race, disability, age, sexual orientation, and religion. While the ECJ has frequently addressed cases related to the first three grounds, the recent judgments in G4S v Achbita and Bougnaoui mark the first instance where the court has been asked to interpret workplace discrimination based on religious grounds...

item.title: Ipsos provides insights on fatigue regarding equal rights in Singapore
item.description:

item.title: The Court of Justice of the European Union makes decisions on cases involving obesity and discrimination laws.
item.description:
Katharina O Cathaoir The European Court of Justice, in its decision on Kaltoft, determined that obesity itself is not a protected characteristic under EU employment law, nor is it automatically a disability. However, the Court acknowledged that the EU Directive prohibiting workplace discrimination based on disability might apply in certain situations. It’s important to note that this ruling specifically pertains to employment disputes, as EU law does not address disability discrimination outside of the workplace...
